creditline: The James Ford Bell Family Foundation Fund, the M. R. Schweitzer Fund, and the Christina N. and Swan J. Turnblad Memorial Fund
description: silver gilt, separates into five parts; fluted foot and bowl with four panels embossed with scenes of the life of the emperor Caligula and capped with a cast and chased figure of Emperor Augustus
text: The twelve Roman emperors were seen as the perfect role models for rulers in the Early Modern period. The present footed bowl, or tazza, is one of twelve, which are now dispersed throughout the world. Since most silver from the Renaissance was molten down in later periods, when it went out of fashion, this is an extremely rare survival. When the twelve tazze were still together in the nineteenth century, the statuettes on top and the lavish scenes on the bowl were mismatched during cleaning. This explains why the present bowl is crowned by the figure of the first emperor, Augustus (63 BCE - 14 CE), whereas the four scenes on the bowl represent episodes from the life of Domitian (51-96 CE).
title: Tazza
